question: [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/state/set_guardian_queue_id_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Missing Validation] The validate() function is completely empty with no validation logic - can an attacker with AdminCap set guardian_queue_id to address(0x0) or invalid ID, breaking oracle guardian queue functionality and causing DoS for all oracle operations requiring guardian verification? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/state/set_guardian_queue_id_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Missing Validation] The empty validate() function performs no checks on guardian_queue_id validity - can an attacker set guardian_queue_id to a non-existent object ID, causing all subsequent guardian queue reads to fail and bricking the oracle system? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/state/set_guardian_queue_id_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Missing Validation] With validate() being a no-op, can guardian_queue_id be set to the same value as the current guardian_queue, creating redundant state changes, wasting gas, and emitting misleading GuardianQueueIdSet events? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/state/set_guardian_queue_id_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Missing Validation] The validate() function doesn't verify that guardian_queue_id points to an actual Queue object - can an attacker set it to an ID of a different object type (e.g., aggregator, feed), causing type mismatches and runtime failures in guardian operations? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/state/set_guardian_queue_id_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Missing Validation] Since validate() is empty, can guardian_queue_id be set to an ID that belongs to a deleted or consumed Queue object, permanently breaking guardian queue functionality until manually corrected? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/state/set_guardian_queue_id_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Missing Validation] The validate() function doesn't check if the new guardian_queue_id is owned by the protocol or is a shared object - can it be set to a privately-owned Queue that later gets transferred or deleted, breaking oracle invariants? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/state/set_guardian_queue_id_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Missing Validation] With no validation, can guardian_queue_id be set to point to a malicious Queue object controlled by an attacker (if AdminCap is compromised), allowing manipulation of guardian attestations? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/state/set_guardian_queue_id_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Missing Validation] The empty validate() doesn't verify Queue configuration (min_stake, reward, max_size) - can guardian_queue_id be set to a Queue with malicious parameters that enable guardian manipulation or DoS? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/state/set_guardian_queue_id_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Missing Validation] Since validate() performs no state consistency checks, can guardian_queue_id be changed during active oracle operations, causing in-flight guardian attestations to reference the wrong queue and fail validation? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/state/set_guardian_queue_id_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Missing Validation] The validate() function doesn't enforce any time-lock or delay - can a compromised AdminCap immediately switch guardian_queue_id to a malicious queue, bypassing any governance or multi-sig protections expected in critical parameter changes? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/state/set_guardian_queue_id_action.move] [Function: run()] [Missing Role Separation] There's no separation between oracle configuration roles and operational roles - can the same AdminCap that manages critical guardian queue settings also perform day-to-day operations, violating principle of least privilege?
